bibl.title: Seventy-six Hindus v. Seattle Department of Immigration. Affidavit of Ellis DeBruler
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.placeName: Western District of Washington Northern Division

div1.p: STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF KING ))) SS:
Bhagat Singh, Nadhan Singh, Nan Singh and Ballah Singh, being first duly sworn, depose and say;

That we came over on the Steamship Minnesota with the seventy-three Hindoo aliens whose cases are before the Honorable Jeremiah Neterer, in the Federal Court, Seattle, Washington, and we know it to be a fact as we have seen the certificates held by the various aliens and we know that each one of them had from one to five or six of these certificates. That the attached paper, signed by an immigration inspector and marked with the letter "A" is a similar sort of certificate to the one received by all of these aliens when they landed in Manila and after they had been examined and passed, and this certificate was taken up by the government at the time of the issuance of certificates similar to this attached, marked "B".

That the affiant, Bhagat Singh, having interpreted for the immigration officers at Manila for a period of approximately one year prior to affiant's leaving the Philippine Islands, and he knows by reason of his having interpreted for the government that the special certificates of registration which were held by all of the aliens involved in this hearing would not have been issued and been given to the aliens unless they had first had certificate "A" which was given them only after a proper admission at Manila and a proper examination,
and after having been passed by the immigration authorities. The other affiants besides Bhagat Singh, testifying herein, know that certificate "A" was only issued after being passed by the immigration board at Manila and a proper examination, and that certificate "A" was absolutely necessary in order to permit aliens to have gotten certificate "B". These affiants all know that this was the method used by the government in Manila and that the holding of certificates similar to "B" signified an examination by the government immigration officals at Manila and a prior holding of a certificate similar to certificate "A". Bhagat Singh further to positive that this affidavit is true as to the method employed by the government at Manila in that he had lost his certificate "A" and endeavored to get a certificate "B" such as was held by all of these seventy-three aliens, and the government informed him that he must have certificate "A" before he could get a certificate "B" and he was compelled to return to the government officers and get from the immigration authorities certificate "A" that is a duplicate of the one which had been given him after his examination before he could secure certificates "B". Bhagat Singh
Mand Singh Mand Singh
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 27th day of Aug. 1913.
Herbert W. Meyers Notary Public in and for the state of Washington residing at Seattle.
